lines.text: A cordial greeting, my worthy friend!
Say, what's the big idea?
I have no ideas. In fact, I'm quite bewildered.
Now, don't get gay with me.
Sir, I'm far from gay.
Where you from, son?
China.
China? You mean where them laundry men come from?
Well, Mr. Mayor!
Good evening, Miss Pratt. Isn't this terrible!
What?
What? I've got to be mayor!
Oh, well its all a circus anyway. And every circus must have its clown.
I got a message for you. Just two words.
And they are?
Lay off!
Lay where?
Wang? Wang? Wang? That chink again!
Now, that's what I like about you. You are so honest in your dishonesty that, at heart, I believe you're honest.
He keeps jabbering about bandits in China. And, now he won't talk to nobody but them chinks in the cellar.
Is that big chink with the sword down there?
Its full of chinks!
Well, what brought you to Stockport?
I was born here.
Eh-huh. A hometown boy, heh? Any friends here?
Well, eh, no. But, I have a letter to Tien Wang, a Chinese gentleman. I'm sure he'll welcome me as a guest.
Say, that ain't right. White man coming back here, no place to go but a Chink.
Why is it that all American girls are so lacking in individuality?
What?
Well, they all look alike. Big-eyed. And pastied-faced. And, well, one exactly like the other.
Eh, how interesting.
Yes, and furthermore, they seem to lack that sense of inferiority that a woman should have in the presence of a man.
Oh, they do?
Yes, I'm disappointed. I doubt whether I shall be able to find an American girl that will make me a suitable wife.
